name: ʿAbd al-Masīḥ b. Maqāra b. Hārūn
description: Christian physician who bought a slavewoman from Sitt al-Munā bt. Natan/Hibatallāh, the widow of Nahray b. Nissim.

name: (Abū ʿAlī) Muḥsin b. Ḥusayn
name_variants: אבו עלי מחסן בן חסין, ابو علي محسن بن حسين
description: representative of the merchants in Fustat; parnas of the Palestinian Rabbanite community in Fustat; descended from a Rabbanite trading family from the northern Syrian coast (Rustow, Heresy, 225)

name: Abū ʿImrān Mūsā b. Ṣadaqa Ibn Nufayʿ
Abū ʿImrān Moshe ha-Kohen Tifʾeret ha-Kohanim
Abū l-ʿAlāʾ b. Bū Sahl al-Jubaylī
Abū l-Bayān b. Barakāt
description: Husband of __ bt. Yusuf who buys 1/48th of a dār from her brother.

name: Abū l-Bishr Shelomo b. Avraham al-Bazzāz
Abū l-Faḍl b. Barakāt b. al-Maqdisī
description: Silk weaver, had four sons.

name: Abū l-Faḍl Maṣliah b. Meshullam al-Ṣayrafī
Abū l-Faraj Nissim b. ʿAmram al-Ṣayrafī
Abū l-Ḥasan ʿAlī b. Ḥasan al-ʿAsqalānī
Abū l-Ḥasan ʿEli b. HIllel al-Baghdādī
description: Son of the scribe and cantor Hillel b. ʿEli. Several documents portray him as a notorious troublemaker.

name: Abū l-Makārim al-Tājir al-Levi b. Abū ʿImrān Mūsā Ibn Nufayʿ
Abū l-Munajjā al-Zariz al-Kohen
description: Collector (jābī) for the Heqdesh in New Cairo in the second half of the 12th century.

name: Abū l-Rabīʿ Sulaymān b. Yehuda ha-Kohen
Abū l-Surur Faraḥ b. ʿAbbās al-ʿAsqalānī
Abū l-Surur Peraḥya b. Menashshe ha-Levi
Abū l-Ṭayyib Mevasser b. Shelomo al-Ṣayrafī
Abū Manṣūr Elʿazar b. Yishaq al-Dimashqī
Abu Naṣr Yehuda b. Yeshuʿa ha-Levi
Abū Saʿīd b. Abū l-Ḥasan al-Abzārī
Abū Sulaymān Dāʾūd b. Abū l-Khaṣīb Zurʿa
Abū Zikrī Kohen
name_variants: Abū Zikrī Yehuda b. Yosef ha-Kohen al-Sijilmāsī
description: Representative of the merchants (wakīl al-tujjār) in Fustat in the 1120s and 1130s and an Indian Ocean trader. Originally from Sijilmāsa.

name: Abū Zikrī Yaḥyā b. Yosef ha-Levi Ibn al-Ḥijāziyya
Aharon b. Yeshuʿa ha-Rofeʾ Ibn al-ʿAmmānī
Aharon b. Yosef ha-Kohen Ibn Sarjado
description: Gaʾon of Pumbedita

name: al-ʿĀdil Ibn al-Salār
description: Born in Jerusalem ca. 1098. Of Kurdish origin. Sunnī. Ascended through the Fatimid military ranks and became governor in turn of Upper Egypt, al-Buḥayra, and Alexandria. Overthrew the vizier Ibn Maṣāl in 1149 and ruled as vizier under the caliph al-Ẓāfir until his own assassination in 1153.

name: al-Malik al-Afḍal
description: Al-Afḍal b. Badr al-Jamālī (d. 1121), was the Fatimid chief wazīr and commander of forces (amīr al-Juyūsh). He was the son of Badr al-Jamālī (d. 1094), the Fatimid wazīr and army commander, and was in office from 1094–1121.

name: ʿAlī b. Manṣūr al-Fawfalī
description: Shipowner (nākhudā) active in the Indian Ocean in the first half of the 12th century. See Ranabir Chakravarti, "Two Men of Boats: ʿAlī b. Manṣūr al-Fawfalī and PDYR—Gleanings from the Cairo Geniza."

name: al-Malik al-ʿAzīz Sayf al-Islām Ṭughtakīn
description: Brother of Saladin; second Ayyubid amir of Yemen.

name: al-Maʾmūn al-Baṭāʾiḥī
description: Abū ʿAbd Allah Muḥammad b. Abū Shujāʿ Fātik al-Baṭāʾiḥī (more accurately Ibn al-Baṭāʾiḥī; d. 522/1128), known as al-Maʾmūn b. al-Baṭāʾiḥī rose to the position of wazīr in 515/1122, following the assassination of the al-Afḍal, and held it until 519/1125, when he was himself arrested and imprisoned. Soon after coming to office in 515 H/1122, he oversaw the construction of al-Jāmiʿ al-Aqmar built by al-ʾĀmir. Before becoming the wazīr, al-Afḍal appointed him as the overseer of his private affairs, at the enviable salary of 130 dinars per month plus other perquisites and benefits, later giving him the title of “al-Qāʾid”.

name: al-Muʿizz b. Bādīs
description: Zīrid ruler of Ifrīqiyya

name: al-Qāḍī Abū l-Maʿālī b. al-Qāḍī al-Mukhliṣ Thiqat al-Mulk
Amat al-ʿAzīz bt. Ḥizqiyyahu
description: Daughter of the Qaraite Nasi Ḥizqiyyahu b. Shelomo b. David.

name: Amīr Fakhr al-Dīn Abū Manṣūr ʿIzz al-ʿArab b. Muḥammad
description: State official active around 1170s in the late Fatimid period. He was a bureaucrat serving under al-Ḥāfiẓ and al-Ẓāfir. In one of the documents, he is sanctioned a medical treatise from the royal library "khizānat al-kutub" of al-Ḥāfiẓ. He is portrayed as a good state official, often intervening on behalf of the dhimmīs for affairs related to the capitation tax.

name: ʿAmmār b. al-Ḥasan b. Ismāʿīl b. ʿAlī
Ammār b. Ezrūn al-Madīnī
description: According to Gil he died in the summer of 1062.

name: ʿAmram b. Ezra
name_variants: עמרם הזקן השלחני בר עזרא ראש הקהל אלאסכנדראני

name: ʿAṭāʾ b. Isḥāq b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Avraham b. Sahlān
description: Ordained by the yeshivas of Jerusalem and Baghdad and head of the Iraqi community in Fustat. Son-in-law of Efrayim he-Ḥaver b. ʿEli b. Ṭarson. Native Egyptian in the seventh generation (from Sunbāṭ). Active from ca. 1017 (TS 16.124). Died in, or shortly before, 1032.

name: Avraham ben Yijū
name_variants: Avraham b. Peraḥya b. Natan ben Yiju ha-Maʿaravi
description: Placeholder

name: Avraham Hamān
description: Merchant active ca. 1800 CE. Often signs letters together with Gavriʾel Ḥefeṣ.

name: Avraham Maimonides
name_variants: Abū l-Munā, Avraham Maymūnī, Avraham b. Moshe b. Maymūn
description: Son of Moshe Maimonides, served as Head of the Jews 1205–37, bearing the title Nagid from 1213 onward.

name: ʿAzarya Zeʾevi
description: Died after 1652 CE. He is mentioned by David Conforte, who knew him personally, in Qore ha-Dorot. He was the son-in-law of Shemuel Ibn Sid. He was among those taken captive by the Bedouin Shaykh Muhammad Ibn Farukh in 1625/6 (see Horvot Yerushalayim, printed in Venice in 1636). ENA 1846.3–4 is a letter that ʿAzarya Zeʾevi later received from Avraham Yakhini (the Sabbatean?) from Istanbul. Evr. II A 1804, an anonymous letter sent to a certain Moshe, mentions a "R. ʿAzarya." (Information from Avraham David.)

name: Badr al-Jamālī
description: Fatimid chief wazir and army commander who served under al-Mustanṣir (d. 1094) from 1073-1094. Originally an Armenian and a convert to Islam, he was initially deployed in Acre before he arrived in Egypt in 1073.

name: Bahāʾ al-Dīn Qarāqūsh b. ʿAbdallāh al-Asadī
description: Eunuch military commander in the service of Saladin and his successors. Died in 1201.

name: Barhūn b. Isḥāq b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Barhūn b. Ismāʿīl b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Barhūn b. Mūsā b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Barhūn b. Ṣāliḥ b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Binyām al-ʿAṭṭār
description: A druggist of Rosetta (Rashīd) active in the early to mid-12th century.

name: Bū l-Makārim Moshe b. Yeḥezqel ha-Levi
Daniʾel b. ʿAzarya
description: [Placeholder]

name: Daughter of Ḥalfon b. Menashshe ha-Levi
David b. Daniʾel (Nasi)
description: Head of the Jews ca. 1082–94, between the two terms of Mevorakh b. Saʿadya. Son of Daniʾel b. ʿAzarya. Vilified in Megillat Evyatar, composed by Evyatar b. Eliyyahu ha-Kohen shortly after David's downfall in 1094 CE.

name: David b. Ṣemaḥ
description: Qaraite Nasi

name: David b. Yiṣḥaq ha-Levi
description: Qaraite courtier

name: David I Maimonides
name_variants: David b. Avraham b. Moshe Maymūnī

name: Dāʾūd b. ʿAmmār b. ʿAzrūn al-Madīnī
Efrayim b. Shemarya
name_variants: (Abū Kathīr) Efrayim b. Shemarya, אפרים החבר ברבי שמריה
description: Head of the congregation of the Shāmīs in Fustat (the one based in the synagogue later called the Ben Ezra). Floruit ca. 1007–1055.

name: Elḥanan b. Ismāʿīl b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Elḥanan b. Shemarya
description: Placeholder

name: ʿEli b. Ḥayyim ha-Kohen ha-Parnas ha-Neʾeman
name_variants: Abū l-Ḥasan ʿAllūn b. Yaʿīsh al-Firnās al-Hārūnī
description: Parnas

name: ʿEli b. Yaḥyā ha-Kohen
description: Parnas

name: ʿEli b. Yiṣḥaq ha-Kohen Ghazāl
description: Beadle (khādim) in the Iraqi synagogue of Fustat.

name: Eliyyahu b. Shelomo ha-Kohen (Gaʾon)
description: Gaʾon of the Palestinian Yeshiva from 1062 to 1083.

name: Eliyyahu b. Zekharya
name_variants: Abū l-Faraj b. Abū Zikrī al-Dayyān al-Iskandarānī, Eliyyahu the Judge
description: See Aryeh Leo Motzkin, “Elijah ben Zechariah: A Member of Abraham Maimuni’s Court: A Geniza Portrait,” REJ 128 (1969), pp. 339–48.

name: Evyatar b. Eliyyahu ha-Kohen (Gaʾon)
description: Gaʾon

name: ʿEzra b. Yishmaʿel b. ʿEzra
description: Wealthy Qaraite

name: Fakhr al-Dawla
description: Ayyubid state official with some connection to Abraham Maimonides. There are at least 12 documents that mention him.

name: Faraḥ b. Yosef b. Faraḥ al-Qābisī
name_variants: Faraḥ b. Yūsuf b. Faraḥ al-Qābisī

name: Fāris al-Dawla
description: The amīr Fāris al-Dawla was active in the 6th/12th century during the period of al-Fāʾiz.

name: Farjūn
description: The most popular man in the geniza. ;-)

name: Fidyār
description: Shipowner (nākhudā) active in the Indian Ocean in the first half of the 12th century.

name: Gabriel Conforte
description: Active in Cairo in the late 17th and early 18th centuries. He may have been the son of the famous David Conforte.

name: Gavriʾel Ḥefeṣ
description: Merchant active ca. 1800 CE. Often signs letters together with Avraham Hamān. His signature resembles חפז, but חפץ is a more typical name and the last letter could be somewhat stylized.

name: Ghālib b. Moshe ha-Kohen
name_variants: Abū Naṣr Ghālib b. Moshe ha-Kohen, Abū Naṣr ha-Kohen Ghālib b. Moshe

name: Ḥalfon b. Netanʾel ha-Levi
name_variants: Abū Saʿīd, Ḥalfon ha-Levi b. Netanʾel
description: Notable India trader; the subject of India Book vol. IV. [placeholder]

name: Ḥamīd al-Dawla
description: Fatimid state official, 11th/12th C.

name: Ḥananʾel b. Shemuʾel
description: [placeholder]

name: Ḥananya b. Yosef ha-Kohen, Av Bet Din
name_variants: Ḥananya Av Bet Din b. Yosef Ga'on
description: Active first decades of the eleventh century (legal document from his court precisely dated to 1007)

name: Hayye bar Sherira
description: Gaʾon of the yeshiva of Pumbedita in Baghdad 998–1038. Born in 939. Author of numerous responsa and legal monographs in Judaeo-Arabic, as well as a commentary on the Mishnah.  Two of Hayye's monographs spread widely in the Middle Ages and were translated into Hebrew more than once: Kitāb al-Aymān, on judicial oaths; and Kitāb al-Shirāʾ wa ʾl-Bayʿ, on the laws of sale. Before serving as gaʾon, Hayye held the position of chief judge (Heb. av bet din) of the yeshiva of Pumbedita. According to Robert Brody (s.v. Hay (Hayya) Gaʾon in EJIW), Hayye was the only gaʾon to serve as his father’s immediate successor. The correct pronunciation of his name is Hayye (the Aramaic form of Ḥayyim), at least according to the rhyme-scheme of a poem published by Shelomo Morag in Tarbiẓ in 1962.

name: Ḥesed b. Yashar al-Tustarī
name_variants: Abū Naṣr al-Faḍl b. Abū l-Faḍl Sahl

name: Hilāl al-Dawla
description: Fatimid state official, served under the administration of al-Āmir. He was sent as a diplomatic envoy and ambassador to the Sulayhid Empress Arwā bt. Aḥmad in Yemen with several gifts including robes that the caliph had worn, dried meat, copies of 12 sermons, and several other priced gifts. (Information from al-Maqrīzī, Ittiʿāẓ III, 103).

name: Hillel b. ʿEli
description: Prominent notary and cantor.

name: Hillel b. Ṣadoq Av Bet Din
Ḥiyya b. Yiṣḥaq
description: The head judge in Fusṭāṭ in the middle of the twelfth century. Active from 1129 until 1170. Author of several legal compositions. The son of the head judge Yiṣḥaq b. Shemuʾel ha-Sefaradi.

name: Ḥizqiyya b. Shelomo b. David
description: Qaraite Nasi

name: Ḥusām al-Dawla
description: Fatimid state official, served under the administration of al-Mustanṣir.

name: Ibn al-Baʿbāʿ
name_variants: Abū Abdallāh, Abū ʿAbdallāh Muḥammad b. ʿAbd al-Raḥmān al-Ṣāʾigh
description: Ibn al-Baʿbāʿ was a Palermitan shipowner and merchant who had business ties with the Geniza merchants in the circle of Nahray b. Nissim, transporting their money, letters and other goods across the Mediterranean. Gil suggests his family were Jewish converts to Islam and perhaps came to Sicily from Andalusia. He was also the last known ruler of Muslim Palermo before the city surrendered to the Normans in 1072.

name: Ibn al-Thumna
description: Ibn al-Thumna was a qāʾid of Sicily in the mid-eleventh century. His base of operations was Catania and Syracuse but Geniza letters mention him in Palermo as well. After a losing battle with a rival qāʾid of Agrigento, Ibn al-Thumna turned to the Normans for help. Geoffrey Malaterra, the late eleventh-century Norman chronicler, describes Ibn al-Thumna's central role in the early years of the Norman conquest of Sicily. He was killed in 1062, a fact celebrated in one Geniza letter.

name: Iftikhār al-Dawla
description: al-Amīr al-Muʾayyad ʿIzz al-Mulk Iftikhār al-Dawla was a Fatimid state official active in the 12th century.

name: Iftikhār al-Dawla Mubārak al-Afḍalī al-Juyūshī
description: Fatimid state official, active around the 6th/12th C.

name: Ismaʿīl b. Yosef b. Abī ʿUqba
Jalāl al-Dawla
description: Jewish state official active in the 13th century and wrote during the time of an epidemic in Fusṭāṭ. His real name was Yishay b. Shelomo. Because of the difficult conditions in Egypt during his time, he thought of moving to Mosul.

name: Karīma bt. ʿAmram (Wuḥsha al-Dallāla)
name_variants: Karīma bt. ʿAmmār, Karīma bt. ʿAmram, Wuḥsha al-Dallāla, וחשה אלדלאלה, כרימה בת עמאר, כרימה בת עמרם
description: Karima bt. ʿAmram/ʿAmmār is more commonly known by her nickname Wuḥsha al-Dallāla. She was a business woman of the late 11th/early 12th century in Fuṣtāṭ. She is one of the most well known women of this time period due to the survival of multiple documents capturing various aspects of her life. She was married to Arye b. Yehudah and had a daughter with him, Sitt al-Ḥasan. Her son, Abū Saʿd, was born out of wedlock after a relationship with Ḥassūn al-‘Asqalānī. For more on her life and business partnerships, see Goitein, "A Jewish Business Woman." RR

name: Karīm al-Dawla ʿAytham
description: One os the state officials of al-Ḥāfiẓ, referred to as ""one of the greatest emirs of al-Ḥāfiẓ" in the document.

name: Karo Frances Co.
name_variants: Karo wa-Fransīs, Karo y Frances, קארו פראנסיס קונפאנייא
description: Company active ca. 1800 comprised of Merkado Karo and Shimʿon Frances.

name: Maḍmūn b. Ḥasan
description: Representative of the merchants in Aden

name: Maḥrūz b. Yaʿaqov
description: Nākhudā (shipowner) traveling between Aden and India

name: Moshe Maimonides
name_variants: Maimonides, Moses Maimonides, Moshe b. Maymūn
description: [placeholder]

name: Makhlūf b. Mūsā Ibn al-Yatīm
name_variants: Ibn ʿAynayn Shirra, Ibn ʿAynayn Sārra, Makhlūf al-Nafūsī, Makhlūf b. ʿAyn Sārra
description: Trader of the late eleventh and early twelfth century. An import-export merchant, he traveled between Iberia and India. Had legal disputes with Ibn Yijū in which he also tried to involve Maḍmūn b. Yūsuf. Ultimately, Maḍmūn paid Makhlūf 300 dinars on behalf of Ibn Yijū and Makhlūf dropped his claims.

name: Makīn al-Dawla
description: The amīr Thiqat al-Mulk Makīn al-Dawla was a state official during the period of the Fatimid caliph al-Ḥakim. Officials by the same title also existed in the periods of al-Mustanṣir and al-Āmir (see T-S 10J14.24, T-S 13J22.23).

name: Makīn al-Dawla
description: Qāḍī of Alexandria during the era of the Fāṭimid caliph al-Mustanṣir.

name: Maʿmūn al-Dawla
description: Fatimid state official.

name: Maṣliaḥ b. Eliyyahu
description: Judge of Palermo in the mid-eleventh century.

name: Maṣliaḥ b. Shelomo (Gaʾon)
description: Gaʾon of the Palestinian yeshiva in Cairo 1127–39.

name: Merkado Karo
description: Merchant active ca. 1800. Formed a company with Shimʿon Frances.

name: Mevorakh b. Natan he-Ḥaver
description: Prolific court scribe

name: Mevorakh b. Saʿadya (Nagid)
name_variants: Abū l-Faḍl Mubārak b. Saʿāda al-Mutaṭabbib
description: Head of the Jews 1078–82 and 1094–1111, bearing the title Nagid from 1094.

name: Mīkhāʾīl b. ʿAbd al-Masīḥ
description: Jahbaz, cashier, worked under the Fatimid administration.

name: Moshe Bibas
description: Merchant active ca. 1800.

name: Moshe b. Mevorakh (Nagid)
description: Succeeded his father Mevorakh as Nagid.

name: Moshe b. Ṣadoq Av Bet Din
Moshe b. Yiṣḥaq ha-Sefaradi
description: A Qaraite who migrated from Spain via North Africa to Jerusalem (see Gil, History of Palestine, sec. 827 and the note to that section).

name: Mubārak b. Hiba
description: Beadle (khādim) of the Babylonian congregation of Fustat in the 1020s.

name: Munīr al-Dawla
description: Munīr al-Dawla al-Juyūshī was the Fatimid governor of Tyre who incited a revolt against the Fatimids in the coastal areas of Palestine like Jubayl and Acre, advancing further south, including Beirut, Sidon, and Tyre. His rebellion together with that of Nāṣir al-Dawla was quashed by the state.

name: Mūsā b. Yaḥyā al-Majjānī
description: Dates ca. 1000–1025

name: Nahray b. Nissim
description:
Abū Yaḥyā Nahray ben Nissim (ca. 1025–98) was a North African merchant and communal leader. More than 350 letters, notes, and accounts from the Cairo Geniza are either addressed to him or written in his hand, comprising one of the largest corpora of documentary sources from the Geniza concerning a single individual.

Born around 1025 and descended from a leader (nagid) of the Qayrawān community, Nahray migrated to Egypt around 1040, where he entered the patronage of his relative Barhūn b. Isḥaq al-Tahartī. At the center of a network of traders plying the Mediterranean in the eleventh century, Nahray was trusted and respected for his ability to determine the market value of commodities. He lived briefly in Alexandria, the center of flax commerce, but eventually settled in Fustat, though he regularly traveled throughout North Africa and visited Palestine at least once. 

Having studied at the Qayrawan academy of Nissim b. Ya`aqov, Nahray was learned in rabbinic literature; he acted as a professional jurisconsult in Fustat and responded to queries from throughout North Africa. He also maintained ties to the Jerusalem academy and received two honorary titles from it. Nahray headed the Iraqi congregation in Fustat and for a time, also managed the affairs of the Palestinian synagogue. He supported the Palestinian nasi David b. Daniel in his conflict with Mevorakh b. Sa'adya between 1082 and 1094, but supported the latter upon his restoration to the headship. In addition, Nahray interacted with officials of the Fāṭimid caliphate on behalf of members of the Rabbanite community and was a generous patron to the needy, ensuring that funds were paid to the heirs of those who had died in international commerce and acting as an agent for orphans. He also raised funds to redeem captives, in one case mobilizing the community to free Jewish merchants held by Byzantine forces in Amalfi. (Information mainly from Phillip Ackerman-Lieberman, "Nahray ben Nissim" in Encyclopedia of Jews in the Islamic World)

name: Nāṣir al-Adīb al-ʿIbrī
description: Poet active ca. 1300 CE. See Alan Elbaum, "Nāṣir, the Hebrew Littérateur," Cambridge University Library, Fragment of the Month, October 2021.

name: Natan b. Avraham (Gaʾon)
description: Rival to Shelomo b. Yehuda for the gaʾonate 1038–42.

name: Natan b. Shelomo ha-Kohen
description: Judge in Fustat

name: Natan b. Saʿadya ha-Kohen Sholal (Nagid)
name_variants: Ibrāhīm al-madʿū Nātān b. Saʿīd b. Nātān, Yonatan b. Saʿadya ha-Kohen
description: Nagid from ca. 1484 until his death in 1502.

name: Neḥemya ha-Kohen b. Kohen Ṣedeq
description: Gaʾon of Pumbedita

name: Netanʾel b. Moshe ha-Levi (Gaʾon)
description: Served as Gaʾon approximately 1160–66 CE. The earliest document invoking his authority is T-S 18J1.26 (PGPID 3515) from 1160, and the latest is T-S NS 308.114 (PGPID 4247) from 1166. He was still alive in 1169 based on Bodl. MS heb. a 3/6.

name: Nissim b. Isḥāq b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Nissim b. Nahray
name_variants: Abū Saʿd, Nissim b. Nahray ha-Rav

name: Nissim b. Yaʿaqov
description: Head of the yeshiva at Qayrawān.

name: Riḍwān b. Walakhshī
description: Riḍwān b. al-Walakshī was a Fatimid wazīr and army commander under the caliph al-Ḥāfīẓ.

name: Saʿadya b. Avraham Ibn al-Amshāṭī
name_variants: Abū l-Fakhr, אבו אלפכר בר אברהם

name: Saʿadya b. Hillel ha-Kohen Rosh ha-Qahal
Saʿadya Gaʾon
name_variants: Saʿadya b. Yosef al-Fayyūmī, Saʿīd b. Yūsuf al-Fayyūmī
description: Gaʾon of Sura 928–942

name: Sahlān b. Avraham
description: Head of the Iraqi congregation of Fustat; active as judge ca. 1034–49 CE

name: Salāma b. Mūsā b. Yiṣḥaq al- Safāquṣī
Sar Shalom ha-Levi (Gaʾon)
name_variants: Abū Zikrī Yaḥyā, Sar Shalom b. Moshe b. Netanʾel ha-Levi
description: Served as head of the Jews in Fustat around 1170/71 and again from around 1173–95. Bore the title gaʾon. Before this appointment he held the post of av bet din in the Palestinian yeshiva in Damascus, under his brother ʿAzarya who was gaʾon in Damascus. In Fustat, succeeded his brother Netanʾel b. Moshe ha-Levi. Moshe Maimonides briefly replaced Sar Shalom ca. 1171 when the Ayyubids came to power and abolished the Fatimid caliphate. The events of Sar Shalom's second tenure (ca. 1173–95) are narrated in Megillat Zuṭa, a scroll authored by a supporter of Maimonides named Avraham b. Hillel, who accuses Sar Shalom and his father Moshe b. Netanʾel ha-Shishi, of gaining the headship of the Jews by corrupt means.

name: Sayyid al-Kull Moshe b. ʿOvadya ha-Ḥazzan Ibn al-Ḥallāʾ
Ṣedaqa b. Netanʾel ha-Ḥazzan Ibn al-Raḥbī
Shabbetay b. Avraham he-Ḥaver ha-Dayyan
description: Judge in Minyat Ziftā

name: Shela b. Mevasser
description: Leader of the Jewish community of Alexandria.

name: Shelomo b. Shemuʾel b. Saʿadya ha-Levi
description: Prolific scribe, including for the works of Maimonides. Active until ca. 1231.

name: Shelomo b. Yehuda (Gaʾon)
name_variants: Shelomo b. Yehuda al-Fāsī, שלמה ברבי יהודה
description: Gaʾon of the Jerusalem yeshiva starting in fall 1025 until his death in 1051. Born ca. 970, either in Fez or to a family from Fez.

name: Shelomo b. Yishay
description: Jewish communal official in the 13th C. He was a Nasi.

name: Shelomo b. Yosef ha-Kohen (Gaʾon)
description: Gaʾon of the Palestinian yeshiva from 1020–25.

name: Shelomo Cesana Co.
description: Merchant with eponymous company active ca. 1800.

name: Shemarya b. Elḥanan
description: Placeholder

name: Shemuʾel b. Moshe he-Ḥaver
name_variants: Shemuʾel he-Ḥaver ha-Meʿulle b. Moshe he-Ḥaver

name: Shemuʾel b. Ḥananya (Nagid)
description: Nagid

name: Shemuʾel b. Ḥofni
description: Gaʾon of Sura 998–1012; died in 1034.

name: Shemuʾel b. Saʿadya ha-Levi
description: Judge and court scribe in Fustat. His sons Yosef and Shelomo were also accomplished scribes.

name: Shemuʾel b. Yaʿaqov ha-Ṣarfati
description:
French rabbi, active in Egypt in the early 13th century
Description from merged entry:
French rabbi [placeholder]

name: Shemuʾel b. Yehuda Ibn Asad al-Tājir
Shemuʾel Sidi
description: Ladino-speaking merchant, active ca. late 17th century.

name: Sherira b. Ḥananya
description: Gaʾon of the yeshiva of Pumbedita in Baghdad. Born ca. 906; rose to the gaonate in 968, and stepped down in 1004 when his son, Hayye, assumed the gaonate; queries continued to be addressed to Sherira and Hayye jointly. Author of numerous responsa, among them a now famous Iggeret penned in 986 in response to Yaʿaqov b. Nissim Ibn Shāhīn in Qayrawān about the composition of the Mishna and other rabbinic literature and the history of the gaonate.

name: Shimʿon Frances
description: Merchant active ca. 1800. Formed a company with Merkado Karo.

name: Sitt Naʿīm
description: Family member of Yefet b. Menashshe ha-Levi and Ḥalfon b. Menashshe ha-Levi; the precise relationship is uncertain.

name: Surūra bt. Ṣāliḥ b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Tāj al-Dawla
description: State official, worked for the fiscal.

name: Thiqat al-Mulk Makīn al-Dawla wa-Amīnuhā
description: Qādī of the Fayyūm during the era of the Fatimid caliph al-Ḥākim.

name: ʿUlla b. Yosef ha-Levi
name_variants: Abū l-ʿAlāʾ Ṣāʿid b. Munajjā al-Dimashqī
description: Parnas

name: Wife of Ḥalfon b. Menashshe ha-Levi
Wife of Khalaf b. Hārūn Tāj al-Maʿālī
Yaʿaqov b. Nissim Ibn Shāhīn
description: Seriously famous. No person page, but I can't resist writing an entry anyway. Philosopher, mathematician, late 10th century; he's the guy who wrote the query that produced the Iggeret Sherira Gaʾon on the redaction of the Mishnah. Author of an Arabic commentary on the Sefer Yeṣirah. Hilariously harsh on the young Saʿadya: claims that when the latter was still in Egypt, he used to address very insignificant questions to Yiṣḥaq b. Shelomo of Qayrawān and comment on medical texts (Galen?) in such a way as to reveal that actually he didn't understand them. So he decided to write his own commentary on Galen, which is still extant. Also wrote a book on Indian mathematics called Ḥisāb al-Ghubār. Father of Rabbenu Nissim, author of a Talmud commentary and head of the yeshiva at Qayrawān. MR

name: Yaʿaqov b. Yosef b. ʿAwkal
description: Placeholder

name: Abū Zikrī Yaḥyā b. Menashshe al-Ṣayrafī
Yedutun ha-Levi
name_variants: Abū l-Ḥasan b. Abū Sahl, Ḥasan b. Sahl
description: Cantor in the Palestinian synagogue in Fustat and prolific payyeṭan. Identified as a physician in two fragments. Associated with the party opposed to the liturgical reforms of Avraham Maimonides. Son of the cantor Abū Sahl Levi b. Ibrāhīm ha-Levi and brother of Moshe b. Levi ha-Levi.

name: Yefet b. Avraham al-Tustarī
name_variants: Abū ʿAlī Ḥasan b. Abū Saʿd Ibrāhīm al-Tustarī
description: Yefet rose at the Fatimid court and by 1064 converted to Islam and was appointed superintendent of the fisc (ṣāḥib bayt al-māl).

name: Yefet b. Yisraʾel b. Mikhaʾel ha-Kohen
Yeḥezqel Ḥefeṣ
description: Prolific scribe and communal rabbi who was active ca. 1780–1830 in Cairo.

name: Yehosef b. Yiṣḥaq b. Shemuʾel ha-Sefaradi
name_variants: Yehosef b. Yiṣḥaq ha-Rav, Yosef b. Yiṣḥaq ha-Dayyan
description: The son of judge Yiṣḥaq b. Shemuʾel ha-Sefaradi. Signed a few court deeds during the first half of the twelfth century - from 1107 to 1153. Mentioned in a colophon he copied or owned, and in a colophon of his son Shelomo. His brother, Ḥiyyā b. Yiṣḥaq, was the head judge of Fusṭāṭ, like their father.

name: Yehoshuaʿ ha-Sar ha-Gadol
description: Appears as communal authority in a sole legal document from Fustat dated 1143/44 CE. Likely identical with Yehoshuaʿ b. Dosa.

name: Abū Zikrī Yehuda b. Moshe Ibn Sughmār
Yehuda b. Saʿadya (Nagid)
description: The first Egyptian Nagid. Served between 1062 and 1064 until his death between 1077 and 1079. See Cohen, Jewish Self-Government, pp. 158–71.

name: Yehūda b. Ṣāliḥ b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Yehuda b. Ṭuviyyahu
description: Muqaddam of Bilbays

name: Yehuda ha-Levi
description: Hebrew poet and author of The Kuzari, a philosophical defense of Judaism. Born in Toledo, died probably on the way to Palestine from Alexandria in 1141. Spent the last year or so of his life in Egypt where he composed numerous poems in honor of various individuals. Also a prolific author of liturgical poetry. Several of his autograph letters survived in the Geniza.

name: Yeshuʿa b. Yosef Ibn Alqāsh
description: A notable figure in the Alexandria Jewish community in the mid- to late 11th century. A Ḥaver. Dealt in the book trade. The Ibn Alqāsh family remained one of the leading Jewish families of Alexandria throughout the 11th and 12th centuries.

name: Yeshuʿa b. Yosef ha-Kohen he-Ḥaver
description: Judge and leader of the Alexandria community. Followed in the footsteps of his father Yosef ha-Dayyan. Yosef was still living when Yeshuʿa assumed leadership of the community. Active until at least 1062 CE, based on T-S 13J28.21 (PGPID 5284) See Frenkel, The Compassionate and Benevolent, pp. 52–73.

name: Yiṣḥaq b. Avraham ha-Kohen Sholal (Nagid)
description: Last Nagid of Egyptian Jews, r. 1502–17 [placeholder]

name: Yiṣḥaq b. Sason ha-Dayyan
description: Judge active in the second half of the 12th century.

name: Yiṣḥaq b. Shemuʾel ha-Sefaradi
description:
Yiṣḥaq b. Shemuʾel ha-Sefaradi was one of two head judges in Fustat from the late 11th century until at least 1127 (together with Avraham b. Shemaʿya). He already appears as an important figure, "the great Rav," in a letter addressed to him by Evyatar Gaʾon, which bears the date 1091. 

Well over a hundred court deeds signed by him have survived in the Geniza. In addition, there are letters sent to him, and letters he wrote to others. 

He had two sons, Yehosef and Ḥiyya. Ḥiyya succeeded him as head judge and was also active for several decades. 

He wrote dozens of liturgical poems, a commentary on the Former Prophets, commentaries on Talmudic tractates, legal compositions on several subjects – which partially survived in the geniza and elsewhere. His compositions are also mentioned in several book lists found in the Geniza.

His signature as 'Sefaradi' shows that he, or his father, immigrated from the Muslim parts of the Iberian peninsula.

name: Yiṣḥaq Castro
description: The son of the better-known R. Yaʿaqov Castro. Conforte wrote about him in Qore ha-Dorot.

name: Yosef b. Shemuʾel b. Saʿadya ha-Levi
description: Court scribe

name: Yosef b. Yaʿaqov Ibn ʿAwkal
name_variants: Abū l-Faraj, Raʾs al-kull, Yūsuf b. Yaʿqūb b. ʿAwkal
description: Placeholder

name: Yosef b. Yaʿqov b. Yosef b. Shemarya b. Menahem
Yosef b. Yeshuʿa ha-Kohen ha-Dayyan
description: Leader of the community of Alexandria from before 1025 until at least 1042. He was succeeded by his son Yosef during his lifetime. He died by 1055. See Frenkel, The Compassionate and Benevolent, pp. 50–52.

name: Yosef Ibn ʿAqnīn
name_variants: Yosef b. Yehuda b. Yosef b. Yaʿaqov
description: Philosopher, ca. 1160–1222. Lived in Seville. Fled al-Andalus some time after the Almohad invasion. See Norman Roth, "Joseph b. Judah Ibn Aknin," in Norman Roth, ed., Medieval Jewish Civilization: An Encyclopedia (New York and London: Routledge, 2003), 341–48.

name: Yosef Khalīfa (Nagid)
description: Among the last Nagids of Egypt, active in the mid- to late 15th century. Succeeded by his son Shelomo. According to Meshullam of Volterra, Yosef served as physician to the sultan.

name: Yūsuf b. Mūsā b. Barhūn al-Tāhartī
Zekharya b. Ḥayyim
description: Late 12th century (letter from 1172), traded in Palermo. Unconfirmed but might be a descendant of the 'Ammar family in 11th century Palermo.
